title: Static friction - different masses on same incline

content.question: Boxes <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> are made of the same material and are both at rest on the same rough incline. Box <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> has mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> and Box <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> has mass <math alttext="2 m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>m</mi></math>. Which of the following claims about the magnitude of the force of static friction exerted on the boxes by the surface is correct?

choices.label: It is the same for both boxes.
It is greater for Box <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math>.
It is greater for Box <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>.
It may or may not be the same depending on the surface area of the boxes in contact with the surface.

content.answer: It is greater for Box <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>.

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
